text: but I've, uh, I was a baby-sitter in high school.  /
And then, just recently, after we were married, I baby-sat for a dentist while she worked.  /
That's the only thing I've ever done also, #is baby-sit.# /
But, uh, I've heard people that I work with talk about, you know, child care.  /
Especially, I guess it's even harder on single mothers. /
Having# to pick up the kid by, you know, six o'clock  /
or it's five dollars for every minute you're late.  And stuff like that <sniffing>. /
I mean, these people can't, you know, #stay there till eight o'clock# --
-- because somebody has to work late  /
See the lady I did it for, - /
that's why she picked me is because I would go to her house so she wouldn't have to get her little girl up.  /
And, uh, then she could be at home  /
and then I'd bring her to my house for a couple of hours if I wanted too or whatever.  /
But, uh, she paid, I think it was two or, I think it was about two fifty, three dollars a hour  /
and by the time I paid taxes on it, it, I was getting like eighty cents  /
and that wasn't counting food or --
The only time I baby-sat was in high school  /
I didn't pay taxes on that,  /
It was easy, you know, go over to some, uh, - /
it was these people that lived in our neighborhood  /
and I'd just go over there.  /
Every Thursday night, they went to the theater.  /
it was supposed to be two dollars an hour for two kids,  /
but they would usually give me like five dollars more #at the end of the night.# /
And, I mean, they'd, you know, - /
and there would be like, uh, you know, there's, we have these videos over #here.  /
And there's some Oreos in the, in the cupboard.  /
and you know, just help yourself to anything.  /
-- it was, it was, you know, the best,  /
that was a long time ago  /
and that was only for a few years.  /
I think people that treat their baby-sitters like that get a lot better baby-sitters. /
And they stick around for longer.  /
Because I mean after I figured out I was getting eighty cents an hour, I said bag it.  /
I was just like but I'm wasting my time.    /
<swallowing> I really liked the little girl and everything  /
and they do take up a lot of your time.  /
Well, and she was really spoiled.  /
They didn't make her eat anything she didn't want or anything.  /
So, basically, they fed her cookies for breakfast and lunch. /
And the mom was a dentist  /
and I was just like, we've got to quit this.  /
And she's like no I don't want her to starve.  /
But I don't want to make her eat something she doesn't want to eat <laughter>. /
So, I can see the concerns on what different people want.  /
I mean, you know, if I was setting up a daycare, there would be so many needs you would have to #customize# --
Cause some parents <noise> won't put up anything.  Where others would. /
I think the best way to go would just be to, to be able to do it out of your basement. /
#And just# have like t-, at the most, like ten kids.  /
And all from maybe people that you #know# --
Instead of trying actually to set up a daycare where you don't know the people coming in and ... -/
I, I'd love to do it.  /
But I just don't trust people now.  /
I just, I think it's a bigger risk than ... -/
cause I'm sure some of them have good reason to sue  /
but I think a lot of them are just, you know, they're negligent  /
and they get happy about money  /
-- they just want to sue you.  /
When you have like a Kindercare or something set up --
-- and th-, when they get greedy or whatever, that's when they have maybe one assistant to twenty kids #or something# /
-- that many little kids getting into things at one time <sniffing>.  /
You know, you never know what they're going to get into. /
I have a girlfriend that works at a daycare  /
and she takes her little girl with her  /
and, I mean, she told me about half the people that they hire  /
and half of them she'd like to turn them into the state <laughter>.  /
And that's the people that are working there, you know.  /
And then she would like to turn in half of the parents that drop their kids off because of the condition the kids are in, you know. /
#Like# they'll be in the same clothes they were the day before, the same diaper. /
but I always think man I just don't know if I could trust anybody.  /
that's a hard thing about it.  /
If, I mean, I don-, I can't foresee myself getting married  /
but if, you know, if I ever wanted to have a kid, how could I work.  /
I mean, I don't think I #could trust somebody with my kid either.  /
-- was a friend that, you know, did it in <hum> {sounds like an airplane} their house that I knew well. /
I just, I couldn't do it I don't think. /
It would just rip me apart, I think <clink>.  /
just besides the fact that, you know, your, when your child gets out of school at three o'clock and then has to wait. /
